title: Old Castle Swifts F.C.
text:
Old Castle Swifts Football Club, the first professional <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> club in <a href="Essex">Essex</a>, was formed by <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> shipowner <a href="Donald%20Currie">Donald Currie</a> in September 1892 as Castle Swifts Football Club. The club's first home ground, located in <a href="West%20Ham">West Ham</a>, was named Dunottar Park, after the Castle Line company's ship <a href="RMS%20Dunottar%20Castle">"Dunottar Castle"</a>. In 1894, Old Castle Swifts merged with Old St Luke's and was renamed. The club was wound up the following season. Its demise saw several players join the newly founded <a href="Thames%20Ironworks%20F.C.">Thames Ironworks</a>, the club that was later reformed as <a href="West%20Ham%20United%20F.C.">West Ham United</a>.
History.
Formation.
Old Castle Swifts Football Club was formed by Scottish shipowner Donald Currie in September 1892 as Castle Swifts Football Club. They were the <a href="works%20team">works team</a> of the ship repair yard of The <a href="Union-Castle%20Line">Castle Shipping Line</a> and initially the majority of the team were drawn from the mainly Scottish workforce, paid for the games they played.
Castles Swifts' first home ground, a field located opposite the <a href="West%20Ham">West Ham</a> Police Station in West Ham Lane, was called "Dunottar Park", after the Castle Line's ship <a href="RMS%20Dunottar%20Castle">Dunottar Castle</a>. The ground had perimeter fencing and admission was charged at 3<a href="History%20of%20the%20English%20penny">d</a>.
1892–1893.
Castle Swifts did not remain long at Dunottar Park, having to find a new ground after a dispute with the landlord. One was soon located in fields beside Wakefield Street in <a href="East%20Ham">East Ham</a>, known as Temple Meadows, which lay in the grounds of Temple House, not far from <a href="East%20Ham%20tube%20station">East Ham railway station</a>. The team would change into their kit in the nearby Denmark Inn (now the <a href="Denmark%20Arms">Denmark Arms</a>), located on the <a href="Barking%20Road">Barking Road</a>. The Denmark Arms would later be used by many West Ham United fans before matches at the <a href="Boleyn%20Ground">Boleyn Ground</a>.
In March 1893 they faced <a href="Barking%20F.C.">Barking Woodville</a> in the final of the <a href="West%20Ham%20Charity%20Cup">West Ham Charity Cup</a>, held at <a href="Clapton%20F.C.">Clapton</a>'s Spotted Dog ground. The Swifts were two goals down before coming back to win the tie 4–2, with the goals coming from outside-right Grundy, inside forwards Mitchell and Taylor and an own goal. 1893–1894.
At the end of the <a href="1893%E2%80%9394%20in%20English%20football">1893–94</a> season, the team merged with Old St Luke's, and the newly formed team was renamed as Old Castle Swifts, and used Old St Luke's ground in <a href="Hermit%20Road">Hermit Road</a>, <a href="Canning%20Town">Canning Town</a>. Hermit Road had been described as a 'cinder heap' and 'barren waste'. It was surrounded by a moat and had canvas sheeting for fencing.
1894–1895.
The Swifts officially became a professional outfit in November 1894, a move made after one of their players, Cunningham, was denied a return to amateur status. The club resigned from the <a href="London%20FA">London FA</a> as a result.
Their demise came at the end of March 1895 when the club became bankrupt. Following this, the club played one further game, a pre-arranged fixture against <a href="St%20Luke%27s%20F.C.%20%28England%29">St Luke's</a> on 16 April, under the name of Old St Luke's.
Thames Ironworks.
<a href="Arnold%20Hills">Arnold Hills</a>, the Chairman of <a href="Thames%20Ironworks%20and%20Shipbuilding%20Co.%20Ltd">Thames Ironworks and Shipbuilding Co. Ltd</a>, saw the opportunity to fund a works side, so provided the money, in order that he may take over the tenancy of the Hermit Road ground, and <a href="Thames%20Ironworks%20F.C.">Thames Ironworks</a> was born. For the Ironworks' initial season of <a href="1895%E2%80%9396%20Thames%20Ironworks%20F.C.%20season">1895–96</a>, a number of Old Castle Swifts players were absorbed into the newly formed team. Among them were half-backs William Morton, Walter Parks and <a href="John%20Thomas%20Archer%20Woods">John Woods</a>, forwards <a href="Jamie%20Lindsay%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201870%29">Jamie Lindsay</a> and <a href="George%20Sage%20%28footballer%29">George Sage</a>, and full-back <a href="Robert%20Stevenson%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201869%29">Robert Stevenson</a>, who became the Ironworks' first ever captain. Goalkeeper <a href="David%20Furnell">David Furnell</a> would also eventually join Thames Ironworks in 1897. The club later became <a href="West%20Ham%20United%20F.C.">West Ham United</a>. The light blue shirts, white shorts and scarlet socks that were worn by Thames Ironworks from the <a href="1897%E2%80%9398%20Thames%20Ironworks%20F.C.%20season">1897–98</a> season, and also by the early West Ham United team, are thought to have originated with Old Castle Swifts.
